To access external devices (â€œScience Journal Sensorâ€) using Science Journal, you must first turn on Bluetooth. In order to discover Science Journal Sensors, Android requires you to also grant permission to access your location because other Bluetooth devices may broadcast their location information during device discovery. However, Science Journal will not store or use this location information, and Science Journal Sensors do not transmit location information.

The ambient light sensor measures light in lux, a measure of illumination that depends on the amount of incoming light and the area over which it is spread.
A full moon provides about 1 lux of illumination, a typical lamp-lit living room about 50 lux, classroom lighting and sunrise and sunset about 400 lux, daylight (indirect sun) over 10,000 lux, and direct sun over 30,000 lux.
Lux is an unfamiliar unit for most of us. When we buy lightbulbs, we often shop by wattsâ€”but the wattage of a bulb doesn\'t tell you how bright a bulb is, only how much energy it uses. Lumens are a better measure for light shopping; they tell you how much light a bulb will actually produce. Lux, meanwhile, tells you how much of that light arrives at a particular area.

Since light spreads out as it travels, the number of lux dwindles as you back away from a light source, even though the source is still emitting the same amount of light in lumens. An area that is tilted away from a light sources also receives less illuminationâ€”which happens to be why the equatorial regions here on Earth are so much warmer than the chilly poles.
By the way, the purpose of the light sensor in your phone is to control the light level of the screen, adjusting accordingly to dim and bright environments. Inside the light sensor, a tiny semiconductor responds to incoming light by producing a small but measurable electrical currentâ€”a phenomenon known as the photoelectric effect. Similar sensors are used in some streetlights to turn them on when it gets dark outside.

Votre tÃ©lÃ©phone comporte un appareil conÃ§u pour dÃ©tecter les champs magnÃ©tiquesÂ : un magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre. Il s\'agit d\'un petit capteur Ã trois axes qui utilise les courants Ã©lectriques pour dÃ©tecter l\'intensitÃ© du champ magnÃ©tique dans les trois dimensions de l\'espace. En associant les donnÃ©es de ces trois axes, nous pouvons crÃ©er un capteur d\'intensitÃ© totale du champ magnÃ©tique.
Certains magnÃ©tomÃ¨tres sont basÃ©s sur l\'effet Hall selon lequel les champs magnÃ©tiques font dÃ©vier la charge en mouvement lorsqu\'elle se dÃ©place. Les modÃ¨les plus rÃ©cents fonctionnent avec des matÃ©riaux magnÃ©torÃ©sistifs, c\'est-Ã -dire des alliages de mÃ©taux dont la rÃ©sistance change en fonction des champs magnÃ©tiques.
Ã€ quoi sert un magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre sur un tÃ©lÃ©phoneÂ ? Ã€ fournir des donnÃ©es sur votre orientation dans l\'espace aux boussoles et aux applications de navigation, en particulier Ã celles proposant des itinÃ©raires dÃ©taillÃ©s.

Le magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre de votre tÃ©lÃ©phone est trÃ¨s sensible aux aimants, courants Ã©lectriques et objets mÃ©talliques environnants. MÃªme au beau milieu d\'un champ ne comportant aucune de ces sources magnÃ©tiques, il affichera toujours un relevÃ© bas non nul, car il rÃ©agit de toute faÃ§on au champ magnÃ©tique de la Terre.

Les objets ont tendance Ã rester immobiles ou Ã rester en mouvement s\'ils l\'Ã©taient au dÃ©part. On appelle cette tendance \"inertie\". La premiÃ¨re loi de Newton l\'Ã©nonce ainsiÂ : un objet demeure Ã l\'Ã©tat de repos ou de mouvement uniforme en ligne droite dans lequel il se trouve, Ã moins qu\'une force dÃ©sÃ©quilibrÃ©e n\'agisse sur lui.
Lorsqu\'une force dÃ©sÃ©quilibrÃ©e entraÃ®ne un mouvement de l\'objet, nous disons que l\'objet accÃ©lÃ¨re. Sa vÃ©locitÃ© ou vitesse change. Elle peut augmenter ou diminuer, ou l\'objet peut changer de direction. L\'accÃ©lÃ©ration est mesurÃ©e en fonction de la variation de la vÃ©locitÃ© (en mÃ¨tres par seconde) sur la durÃ©e, ou en mÃ¨tres par seconde carrÃ©e (m/sÂ²).
Votre tÃ©lÃ©phone dispose d\'un appareil permettant de mesurer ces changements de mouvementÂ : un accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre. L\'accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre se compose de petites masses suspendues libres de leurs mouvements. Les changements de mouvement entraÃ®nent un dÃ©placement de ces masses, de mÃªme que votre tÃªte est entraÃ®nÃ©e vers l\'avant lorsque vous Ãªtes dans une voiture qui freine brusquement. En mesurant ces lÃ©gers dÃ©placements, l\'accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre de votre tÃ©lÃ©phone peut dÃ©tecter des changements de mouvement et de direction, ce qui est trÃ¨s utile pour lui permettre de passer du mode portrait au mode paysage (et vice versa), pour les jeux vidÃ©o et bien d\'autres applications.

Vous avez probablement remarquÃ© une accÃ©lÃ©ration continue sur l\'axeÂ Z, mÃªme lorsque votre tÃ©lÃ©phone est posÃ© sur une table. Il s\'agit de l\'accÃ©lÃ©ration que nous ressentons ici, Ã la surface de la Terre, en raison de la force de gravitÃ©. Elle est d\'environ 9,8Â m/sÂ².

Les sons proviennent des vibrations. Par exemple, votre voix est Ã©mise par les vibrations des cordes vocales de votre gorge. Ces vibrations crÃ©ent des zones alternÃ©es de haute et basse pression d\'air qui se propagent vers l\'extÃ©rieur, un peu comme des ondulations circulaires qui apparaissent lorsque vous jetez un caillou dans un Ã©tang.

Tous les sons peuvent Ãªtre dÃ©crits en termes de frÃ©quence et d\'intensitÃ©.
L\'intensitÃ© est ce que vous mesurez avec le capteur d\'intensitÃ© sonore de ScienceÂ Journal et s\'exprime en dÃ©cibels (dB). L\'intensitÃ©, ou la sonie, dÃ©pend de la distance parcourue par l\'objet en mouvement Ã chaque vibration. Nous percevons une intensitÃ© plus importante lorsque la sonie augmente.
La frÃ©quence (ou hauteur, ou ton) d\'une onde sonore Ã©quivaut Ã son taux de vibration. Plus un objet vibre vite, plus la hauteur du son Ã©mis est Ã©levÃ©e. Le capteur d\'intensitÃ© sonore de ScienceÂ Journal ne mesure pas la frÃ©quence, mais seulement la sonie.
Il faut savoir que le microphone de votre appareil est conÃ§u pour Ãªtre trÃ¨s sensible aux diffÃ©rences d\'ondes sonores dans le temps, mais pas Ã la taille absolue de chaque onde. Nous avons essayÃ© de choisir un code susceptible de gÃ©nÃ©rer des donnÃ©es similaires aux rÃ©fÃ©rences prÃ©sentÃ©es ci-dessous, mais chaque appareil peut invariablement fournir des donnÃ©es plus ou moins Ã©levÃ©es. Les scientifiques Ã©talonnent gÃ©nÃ©ralement un capteur comme celui-ci en fonction d\'une mesure connue. Pour l\'instant, ScienceÂ Journal peut vous indiquer si votre prochain voyage en train sera plus bruyant que le concert de rock auquel vous assisterez, mais seulement si vous utilisez le mÃªme tÃ©lÃ©phone dans les deuxÂ situations.
Sachez Ã©galement qu\'il existe d\'importantes diffÃ©rences entre l\'intensitÃ© du son, le niveau d\'intensitÃ© du son et la pression acoustique. Nous utilisons ici ces termes indiffÃ©remment, mais si vous souhaitez en savoir plus, vous trouverez de nombreuses ressources en ligne expliquant leurs caractÃ©ristiques.
Le son le plus discret que l\'oreille d\'un Ãªtre humain lambda peut percevoir est de zÃ©ro dÃ©cibel. Une conversation ordinaire atteint environ 60Â dB, et les sons supÃ©rieurs Ã 140Â dB sont douloureux pour l\'oreille humaine. Cependant, mÃªme les sons qui ne font pas mal peuvent Ãªtre dangereux. Une exposition continue Ã des sons de 90Â dB (ce qui Ã©quivaut Ã la sonie d\'un aspirateur) peut entraÃ®ner une perte de l\'audition.
L\'Ã©chelle des dÃ©cibels est logarithmique, ce qui peut Ãªtre assez trompeurÂ : une source sonore de 40Â dB n\'est pas deux fois plus intense qu\'une source de 20Â dB. Elle est en rÃ©alitÃ© 100Â fois plus intense. Dans le mÃªme temps, si l\'alarme d\'un rÃ©veil gÃ©nÃ¨re 70Â dB, deux alarmes ne produiront pas 140, mais 73Â dB. Cette Ã©chelle fonctionne en effet Ã©trangement.
10Â dBÂ : bruissements de feuilles 20Â dBÂ : chuchotement Ã 1,50Â m 30Â dBÂ : lÃ©ger chuchotement 50Â dBÂ : pluie 60Â dBÂ : conversation normale 90Â dBÂ : mixeur 100Â dBÂ : voiture sans silencieux 110Â dBÂ : cri dans l\'oreille 120Â dBÂ : tonnerre 130Â dBÂ : marteau-piqueur 140Â dBÂ : dÃ©collage d\'un avion

Les sons proviennent des vibrations. Par exemple, votre voix est Ã©mise par les vibrations des cordes vocales de votre gorge. Ces vibrations crÃ©ent des zones alternÃ©es de haute et basse pression d\'air qui se propagent vers l\'extÃ©rieur, un peu comme des ondulations circulaires qui apparaissent lorsque vous jetez un caillou dans un Ã©tang.

Tous les sons peuvent Ãªtre dÃ©crits en termes de frÃ©quence et d\'intensitÃ©. La frÃ©quence (ou hauteur, ou ton) d\'une onde sonore Ã©quivaut Ã son taux de vibration. Plus un objet vibre vite, plus la hauteur du son Ã©mis est Ã©levÃ©e. Ces vibrations s\'expriment en Hertz (Hz), oÃ¹ 1Â HertzÂ =Â 1Â vibration/seconde.
Les frÃ©quences sonores pouvant Ãªtre perÃ§ues par un Ãªtre humain vont de 20 Ã 20Â 000Â Hz. La touche d\'un piano correspondant Ã la note la plus grave produit un son d\'une frÃ©quence de 27,5Â Hz, tandis que la touche correspondant Ã la note la plus aiguÃ« produit un son d\'une frÃ©quence de 4Â 186,01Â Hz.
Le point rouge indique l\'Ã©cart entre la hauteur dÃ©tectÃ©e et la note la plus proche. Si la hauteur est grave ou \"en dessous\", le point apparaÃ®t sur la gauche. Si la hauteur est aiguÃ« ou \"au-dessus\", le point rouge apparaÃ®t sur la droite.

Le tour par minute (tr/min) est une unitÃ© permettant de mesurer la frÃ©quence de rotation autour d\'un axe fixe en une minute.
Lorsque votre girouette tourne, elle entraÃ®ne une rotation du disque codeurÂ :
Cela est interprÃ©tÃ© en pÃ©riodes de lumiÃ¨re et d\'obscuritÃ© par le capteur et enregistrÃ© dans ScienceÂ Journal en tant que rotation.

Le Bluetooth est une norme de technologie sans fil qui utilise les ondes radio pour Ã©changer des donnÃ©es sur de courtes distances, Ã partir d\'appareils fixes et mobiles.

Sans mÃªme nous en rendre compte, nous vivons au fond d\'un profond ocÃ©an d\'air, l\'atmosphÃ¨re terrestre, qui s\'Ã©lÃ¨ve Ã plus de 40Â km au-dessus de la surface de la Terre. Le poids de cette masse d\'air au-dessus de nos tÃªtes est appelÃ© pression atmosphÃ©rique.
Au niveau de la mer, la pression atmosphÃ©rique exerce une force d\'environ 1Â kg par centimÃ¨tre carrÃ©, l\'Ã©quivalent de 625Â kg exercÃ©s sur la surface d\'une feuille A4.

Nous ne remarquons pas cette pression Ã©crasante parce que nous y sommes habituÃ©s, du moins jusqu\'Ã ce que celle-ci change, mÃªme trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨rement. C\'est le cas lorsque nous montons en altitude ou que nous prenons l\'avion. La pression atmosphÃ©rique varie Ã©galement en fonction des conditions mÃ©tÃ©orologiquesÂ : elle diminue lorsque le temps est orageux et instable, et augmente lorsqu\'il se stabilise et s\'Ã©claircit.
Le baromÃ¨tre numÃ©rique prÃ©sent dans votre tÃ©lÃ©phone mesure la pression atmosphÃ©rique en hectopascals (un hectopascal est Ã©gal Ã 100Â pascals, et un pascal correspond Ã une force d\'un newton exercÃ©e sur une surface d\'un mÃ¨tre carrÃ©). Vous avez peut-Ãªtre dÃ©jÃ entendu les prÃ©sentateurs mÃ©tÃ©o parler de pression atmosphÃ©rique en millibarsÂ : cette unitÃ© est Ã©quivalente Ã l\'hectopascal.
Vous vous demandez probablement pourquoi un tÃ©lÃ©phone mesure la pression. La pression atmosphÃ©rique Ã©volue de maniÃ¨re mesurable pour tout changement, mÃªme minime, d\'altitude (par exemple, lorsque vous montez un escalier). Le baromÃ¨tre numÃ©rique intÃ©grÃ© Ã un tÃ©lÃ©phone peut donc servir Ã dÃ©tecter des changements de position, en vous indiquant par exemple Ã quel Ã©tage d\'un immeuble vous vous trouvez, ou si vous Ãªtes au-dessus ou en dessous d\'un pont.

The Arduino Science Journal is one of the BETT Award 2021 Finalist in the \"FREE DIGITAL CONTENT OR OPEN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES\" category.
The Arduino Science Journal (formerly Science Journal, an initiative by Google) is free and open-source, and allows you to gather data about the world around you by harnessing the sensors in your smartphone as well as sensors connected to Arduino, or other third party hardware. The Science Journal transforms smartphones, tablets, and Chromebooks into science notebooks that encourage students to explore their world.
The Arduino Science Journal app is recommended for students from 10 to 18 years of age, and is available in 45 languages.
About the Science Journal
With the Arduino Science Journal, you can learn interactively, conduct experiments and iterate on findings.
â€¢ ğŸ’ª Enhance your existing lesson plans: use the Science Journal with activities and assignments you have already prepared â€¢ âœï¸ Classroom & home-school friendly: you donâ€™t have to be in a classroom setting to start exploring. The Arduino Science Journal can be used to run experiments straight away, as long as you have your smartphone or tablet with you! â€¢ ğŸŒ± Move learning outside: the use of mobile devices along with the types of experiments we offer encourage students to get out of their seats and open their eyes to the world around them through the power of science â€¢ ğŸ” Science and data have no secrets: you can easily record your observations, store your data sensors in real-time and analyse them, just as a proper scientist! â€¢ ğŸ”„ Connect the digital and the physical world from your pocket: go through a series of simple tutorials and start having fun with science
It transforms different devices such as smartphones, tablets, and Chromebooks, into a pocket-size science tool that encourages you to explore your world. As students conduct experiments, theyâ€™ll record observations and make new, exciting discoveries. Through documentation and reflections, students can conduct experiments just like any other scientist. You can use the app as it is, using the sensors included in your smartphone or tablet, or use external hardware like sensors and microcontrollers that are compatible with bluetooth connections, to run more demanding experiments. By using external sensors, the students can extend their experimentation and learning. For a more in-depth experience of the world of science, the app comes with different topic-related lessons - available for students and teachers alike!
The app is classroom-friendly, since students can sign in on any device and access their experiments to continue exploring the world, wherever they are!
Permissions notice: â€¢ ğŸ“Location: Needed to scan for Bluetooth sensor devices. â€¢ ğŸ“· Camera: Needed to take pictures to document experiments. â€¢ ğŸ™Microphone: Needed for sound intensity sensor. â€¢ ğŸ“¥Storage: Needed to access photos to insert into experiments.
Benefits of using the Arduino Science Journal â€¢ Itâ€™s free and simple to use â€¢ Easy setup: download the app and start exploring with your phoneâ€™s built-in sensors â€¢ Cross-platform: supports Android, iOS, and Chromebooks â€¢ Portable: enhance your home learning or bring your device outside to study the world around you â€¢ Safe for children to use: COPPA Compliance underway â€¢ Fully compatible with Arduino hardware: keep experimenting with the Arduino Science Kit Physics Lab, as well as the Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense board â€¢ Compatible with third-party hardware â€¢ Fully open-source: you can develop your own hardware support as the app is open-source â€¢ Google Drive integration (coming soon), as well as local download

L\'orientation du tÃ©lÃ©phone par rapport au champ magnÃ©tique de la Terre.

La Terre est entourÃ©e d\'un champ magnÃ©tique, que vous pouvez dÃ©tecter avec le magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre de votre tÃ©lÃ©phone. Les donnÃ©es de ce magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre associÃ©es aux informations d\'orientation du tÃ©lÃ©phone dans l\'espace permettent de crÃ©er une boussole numÃ©rique.
La boussole classique est un magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre basique dont l\'aiguille aimantÃ©e tourne pour s\'aligner avec le champ magnÃ©tique environnant. Votre tÃ©lÃ©phone n\'est pas Ã©quipÃ© d\'une mini-boussole, mais d\'un tout petit capteur Ã trois axes qui utilise les courants Ã©lectriques pour dÃ©tecter l\'intensitÃ© du champ magnÃ©tique dans les trois dimensions de l\'espace. Ce capteur ne suffit bien entendu pas Ã crÃ©er une boussole.
Pourquoi une boussole doit-elle associer les donnÃ©es issues du magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre aux informations d\'orientation du tÃ©lÃ©phoneÂ ? En connaissant ces derniÃ¨res, nous pouvons calculer la rotation magnÃ©tique mÃªme lorsque le tÃ©lÃ©phone ne se trouve ni Ã plat, ni sur le mÃªme plan que le champ magnÃ©tique de la Terre. Nous savons que la gravitÃ© est perpendiculaire au champ magnÃ©tique de la Terre, nous pouvons donc utiliser la direction de la gravitÃ© indiquÃ©e par les capteurs de l\'accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre pour dÃ©terminer quelle part du champ magnÃ©tique est sur le mÃªme plan que le champ magnÃ©tique de la Terre.

Comme vous avez pu le constater, la boussole rÃ©agit Ã n\'importe quel champ magnÃ©tique environnant (aimants, courants Ã©lectriques et objets mÃ©talliques), et pas seulement Ã celui de la Terre. Ses relevÃ©s vont donc varier. Pour vous assurer que l\'aiguille rouge de la boussole est alignÃ©e avec le champ magnÃ©tique de la Terre, placez-vous dans un lieu ouvert (de prÃ©fÃ©rence, en extÃ©rieur et loin des lignes Ã©lectriques). Effectuez un mouvement en forme de huit avec votre tÃ©lÃ©phone pour faciliter le calibrage du magnÃ©tomÃ¨tre.
L\'accÃ©lÃ©ration totale du tÃ©lÃ©phone en m/sÂ², Ã l\'exception de la force de gravitÃ©.

Lorsqu\'une force dÃ©sÃ©quilibrÃ©e entraÃ®ne un mouvement de l\'objet, nous disons que l\'objet accÃ©lÃ¨re. Sa vÃ©locitÃ© ou vitesse change. Elle peut augmenter ou diminuer, ou l\'objet peut changer de direction. L\'accÃ©lÃ©ration est mesurÃ©e en fonction de la variation de la vÃ©locitÃ© (en mÃ¨tres par seconde) sur la durÃ©e, ou en mÃ¨tres par seconde carrÃ©e (m/sÂ²).
Votre tÃ©lÃ©phone dispose d\'un appareil permettant de mesurer ces changements de mouvementÂ : un accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre. L\'accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre se compose de petites masses suspendues libres de leurs mouvements. Les changements de mouvement entraÃ®nent un dÃ©placement de ces masses, de mÃªme que votre tÃªte est entraÃ®nÃ©e vers l\'avant lorsque vous Ãªtes dans une voiture qui freine brusquement. En mesurant ces lÃ©gers dÃ©placements, l\'accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre de votre tÃ©lÃ©phone peut dÃ©tecter des changements de mouvement et de direction, ce qui est trÃ¨s utile pour lui permettre de passer du mode portrait au mode paysage (et vice versa), pour les jeux vidÃ©o et bien d\'autres applications.
Le capteur de l\'accÃ©lÃ©romÃ¨tre linÃ©aire enregistre l\'accÃ©lÃ©ration totale sur les trois axes du tÃ©lÃ©phone, Ã l\'exception de la gravitÃ©.

Experiment data for Science Journal is saved and made available across devices using Google Drive and requires signing in with a Google account.
If you have existing data on this device, once signed in, you can save your existing experiments to Google Drive. Your experiments are stored in a \u201CScience Journal\u201D folder in Google Drive.
Les paramÃ¨tres de l\'appareil existants ont Ã©tÃ© appliquÃ©s Ã ce compte
L\'application ScienceÂ Journal doit Ãªtre activÃ©e dans la console d\'administration Google par l\'administrateur de votre domaine.

Using augmented reality, track and measure objects
Ajouter une note Ã la chronologie
The amount of flow of charged particles between two places
A device that measures orientation and angular velocity (rotation).
An instrument used to measure the intensity and direction of a magnetic field
The measure of the difficulty of current flow through an object or material
The difference in electric potential between two places that allows a current to flow
Ambient temperature in C or F
A barometric sensor is used to measure air pressure in a certain environment. Air Pressure can impact short term changes in the weather. The Barometric Air Pressure is measured in Atmosphere or atm.
A humidity sensor is an electronic device that measures the humidity in its environment and converts it into an electrical signal. Relative humidity is measured in %.
The ambient light sensor measures light in lux, a measure of illumination that depends on the amount of incoming light and the area over which it is spread. The amount of light is measured in lux.

Color temperature is a characteristic of visible light that has important applications in many industries, such as: lighting, photography, astrophysics, manufacturing, and other fields. Color temperature is expressed in Kelvins (K), a unit of measurement for absolute temperature.
The CIE 1931 x,y chromaticity space, also showing the chromaticities of black-body light sources of various temperatures (Planckian locus), and lines of constant correlated color temperature.

A proximity sensor is a sensor able to detect the presence of nearby objects without any physical contact. A proximity sensor often emits an electromagnetic field or a beam of electromagnetic radiation (infrared, for instance), and looks for changes in the field or return signal. The object being sensed is often referred to as the proximity sensor\'s target. Proximity here is measured in millimeters or mm.
Weâ€™re done checking for permissions. If you need to modify these permissions in the future, you can do so at any time in the Science Journal app settings of the Android Settings app.
Start taking notes and record data using the observation toolbar.
Find activities and inspiration at science-journal.arduino.cc and start exploring the world around you.
If you missed the Getting Started guide or you want to go back to it, you can find it in the sidebar menu.
This introduction will walk you through the most important functions of Science Journal and show you how to turn your smart device into a pocket science lab. Swipe left to begin.
You can always get back to this intro later in the sidebar menu.
Science Journal helps you to conduct science experiments by allowing you to observe real time sensor data, record sensor values as well as add notes and observations to your experiments.
Did you know that smartphones come with various built-in sensors? Connect an Arduino board to add even more advanced sensors.
Add a new experiment to start exploring & journaling
An experiment lets you organise all your observations and recordings of a specific topic. Create a new experiment, give it a suitable name and start exploring the sensors.
Add a picture from your gallery
Document different types of observations through the observation toolbar. You can add a text note or photo to your experiment or create a sensor recording.
Pick a built-in phone sensor or connect an Arduino board to see live sensor data.
You can add multiple sensors to your experiment to observe them simultaneously.
To capture sensor data and save it to your experiment you can either start a recording or you can use the snapshot function.
Start a recording to capture the change of sensor values over time.
Create a point-in-time snapshot to capture the current sensor values.
It can be challenging to look at the display while doing an experiment. Tap â€œEnable audioâ€ to transform sensor values into audible sound.

All your experiments can now be saved and accessed from anywhere with the Cloud Sync feature. By tapping on the \"Google Drive\" button you are agreeing to Googleâ€™s permission and privacy policy to enable the backup, and sync of your experiments in a Google Drive folder of your choice, in accordance with Google T&Cs and privacy policy. You will be redirected to Googleâ€™s authentication page to complete your Cloud Sync.

The Arduino Science Journal app and Arduino never access your experiments created in the App, as they are only saved locally, nor do they access your documents in Google Drive, under any circumstances, even when Cloud Sync is active. The Arduino Science Journal app will ask for your permission to see, create and delete files with the sole purpose of saving and backing up your experiments in a Google Driveâ€™s folder of your choice. You can change your preferences at any time straight from your Google account, or you can decide to revoke Cloud Syncâ€™s access directly from the App. If you use a Google Account through your organization or school, you may not be able to back up your files. Check with your administrator first. If you have any doubt about Google Drive policies and/or if you have any problems related to the updates of Google Drive, please contact directly Google, as only the latter can help you deal with problems on your Google Drive account and folders. If you have any doubts or questions about Google\'s policies, permissions and privacy policies, please read Googleâ€™s T&Cs and privacy policy.
Choose where you would like to save your experiments
Your experiments will be automatically synced in the folder â€œ%sâ€ on your Drive.
Enter the email address associated with your account below.
Check your email, we just sent you a link to complete the reset of your password.
We need to know this in order to create the right account type for you.
I would like to receive emails about special deals and commercial offers from Arduino.
I would like to receive the Arduino newsletter.
We sent you an email to finalize your registration. In order to continue, please follow the instructions and activate your account. Once your account is activated, you can login to Science Journal.
Sign in with a Junior account
This extra step shows that itâ€™s really you trying to sign in. Get a verification code from the Authenticator app.
The username is the word you used to sign in to your account. If you do not remember your username, ask your parent to restore your account from their Arduino profile page.
Ask your parent to check their email inbox to reset your accountâ€™s password.
A parent needs to help you create the account. Enter their email address below and we will send instructions on how to proceed.
You may use the following actions to collect, export or discard those experiments:
Delete an experiment from the device
Experiment data for Science Journal can be saved and made available across devices using Google Drive which requires signing in with a Google Account.
If you have existing data on this device, once signed in, you can save your existing experiments to Google Drive. Your experiments are stored in a folder of your choice in Google Drive.
Error connecting to Google Drive. Please try again.
Choose where you would like to save your experiments
Your experiments will be automatically synced in the folder â€œ%1$sâ€ on your Drive.
The experiment has been modified from another device
A network error occurred, please check your connection and try again.
An error occurred. Please try again.
Enter your birth date below to continue and ensure the data is correct: it will determine the type of account created for you.
Email and confirmation do not match
Only letters, numbers, hyphen (-) and underscore (_) are allowed. Your username must start with a letter or number and be at least 3 characters long.
I have read the Privacy Policy and accept the Terms of Service. *
I want to see personalised commercial offers from Arduino based on my browsing and purchasing behaviour.
Username or email already registered. Please go back and check.
Enter your username and the parentâ€™s email associated with your account below.
User not found. Please check and try again.

The username is created for you automatically, but you can generate new ones until you find the best one. You will use this username to log in to Arduino, and other users will see it when you post projects.
We sent an email with instructions to your parentâ€™s email %1$s. You will be able to sign in once they finalize your account.
Are you sure you want to Sign Out?
There is one experiment on the device which donâ€™t belong to anyone. Tap â€œCollectâ€ to assign yours to your virtual lab.
There are %1$d experiments on the device which donâ€™t belong to anyone. Tap â€œCollectâ€ to assign yours to your virtual lab.
If you would like to assign previous experiments to %1$sâ€™s Lab you can collect them here.
Are you sure to collect all experiments and add them to your accountâ€™s lab: %1$sâ€™s Lab?
There are no experiments in %1$sâ€™s Lab
Are you sure to collect this experiment and add it to your accountâ€™s lab: %1$sâ€™s Lab?
Sign in with your Google account to start using drive sync
Are you sure you wish to disable your Google Drive Sync? If you confirm, your experiments will no longer be saved, and backed up to your Google Drive.
Congrats! Your Google Drive Account has been successfully set up. All your experiments will now be saved and backed up in the folder below.
The Cloud Sync will start shortly. It may take some minutes to complete.
By signing up you are agreeing to Arduino Terms of Service, and Privacy Policy
